Moore hardens criticism of Trump after ‘conspiracy theories and attacks’ Maryland Gov. Wes Moore (D) on Monday took a hardened stance toward what he described as a “full crisis situation” manufactured by the still-new Trump administration, a shift in tone after months of careful political maneuvering to preserve any cooperation that the deep-blue state could get from the federal government. Moore had greeted President Donald Trump’s election victory in November by saying he wanted to work to find “common ground” with the incoming president, as long as he could also protect the interests of Maryland residents. Over the past five weeks, he said, that goal has increasingly seemed unattainable, and on Monday he accused Trump of “kicking children off of Medicaid so we can make space in the budget for tax cuts for billionaires.” In a response to Moore’s criticisms, the White House struck back at Democrats who have slammed the recent cuts to federal jobs and spending under the guidance of the Elon Musk-led U.S. DOGE Service, also known as the Department of Government Efficiency. “The Democrats have no plan on how to recover from their embarrassing loss, and it shows,” White House spokesman Harrison Fields said in an email. “Instead of working to become a party that focuses on the will of the people, they are hell-bent on keeping their heads in the sand and gaslighting on the widely supported mission of DOGE.” Trump last week appointed Moore to the bipartisan Council of Governors, which works to strengthen state and federal partnerships on national security, disaster response and military coordination. Moore attended a meeting of governors from across the country in D.C. on Friday. Moore said Republican and Democratic governors had productive and interesting conversations about policy. When Trump showed up, Moore said, it became clear that he did not intend to listen to the state leaders. “When the president of the United States walked into the room, that’s when things went off the rails,” he said. Trump clashed with the Democratic governor of Maine over an executive order that bans transgender athletes from competing on girls’ and women’s sports teams, and he threatened to withhold all federal funding from the state if it does not comply. Moore described the president’s remarks as “an hour-long diatribe of conspiracy theories and attacks on my colleagues.” “I’ve come back from these meetings with all of our nation’s governors … with a full-blown understanding that this is a full crisis situation,” Moore said. “It’s time for all of us to take this moment seriously.” Already facing a $3 billion budget deficit, Maryland stands to lose a lot amid the administration’s efforts to shrink the federal government and reduce spending. The state is home to many federal workers who have either lost their jobs in recent weeks or are in danger of losing them amid the Trump administration’s spending cuts. Government contractors and nonprofits who depend on federal grants are also laying off workers and closing shop. Other changes being contemplated by the administration and a Republican-controlled Congress would further devastate Maryland’s economy, Moore said. Those actions could soon include cuts to Medicaid, reductions in Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program benefits and a full shutdown of the federal government that would leave tens of thousands of Marylanders temporarily out of work, he said. The governor said he left D.C. on Friday with the feeling that the Trump administration relishes the potential fallout from those decisions. “Not only is this going to continue; they are going to accelerate,” Moore said. For months, Moore and other Democratic leaders have been trying to navigate the tension between protecting whatever federal resources they can get for their states and voicing their concerns about the president’s words and actions. Moore was photographed in December smiling and shaking hands with Trump at the Army-Navy football game, a gesture to show good faith. By the time Moore gave his State of the State address early this month, his rhetoric had begun to shift. He didn’t name Trump, but he lamented the “uncertainty, confusion and chaos” of the first few weeks of the new administration. Less than a month after that speech, Moore on Monday shared doubts that a partnership can exist between the deeply blue state and the Trump White House. Moore said governors in both parties were willing to work together on some issues, especially to build a strong economy, but Trump did not engage in the bipartisan conversation. “I don’t think that anybody, either Democrat or Republican, could walk away from what happened this weekend and say that same measure of cohesion existed between our nation’s governors and the White House,” he said.
